playn.core

Interface Pointer

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    PointerImpl

    public interface Pointer
    Input-device interface for pointer events. This is a generic interface that works for both mouse and touch events, but only handles the basic touch-drag-release case.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Interface and Description
      static class  Pointer.Adapter
      A Pointer.Listener implementation with NOOP stubs provided for each method.
      static interface  Pointer.Event
      The event dispatched to pointer listeners.
      static interface  Pointer.Listener 

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void cancelLayerDrags()
      Cancels any currently active drag interaction on a layer.
      boolean isEnabled()
      Returns true if pointer interaction is enabled, false if not.
      Pointer.Listener listener()
      Returns the currently configured global pointer listener, or null.
      void setEnabled(boolean enabled)
      Allows pointer interaction to be temporarily disabled.
      void setListener(Pointer.Listener listener)
      Sets the listener that will receive pointer events.

    • Method Detail

      • isEnabled

        boolean isEnabled()
        Returns true if pointer interaction is enabled, false if not. Interaction is enabled by default. See setEnabled(boolean).

      • setEnabled

        void setEnabled(boolean enabled)
        Allows pointer interaction to be temporarily disabled. No pointer events will be dispatched whilst this big switch is in the off position.

      • listener

        Pointer.Listener listener()
        Returns the currently configured global pointer listener, or null.

      • setListener

        void setListener(Pointer.Listener listener)
        Sets the listener that will receive pointer events. Setting the listener to null will cause pointer events to stop being fired.

      • cancelLayerDrags

        void cancelLayerDrags()
        Cancels any currently active drag interaction on a layer. This does not cancel a drag interaction being managed by the global pointer listener. This is useful if you are implementing "overlapping" interactions, like the ability to click on buttons and also the ability to flick scroll an entire interface. You might start an interaction by clicking a button, but then turn that interaction into a flick scroll by flicking your finger. Your code should then cancel the button interaction so that the user does not accidentally end up clicking the button if they happen to move finger in just the right way.
